General.definition: The occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
General.example: Discovering the hidden café was pure serendipity.

General.definition: Lasting a very short time.
General.example: The beauty of the sunset is ephemeral.

General.definition: Pleasantly smooth and musical to hear.
General.example: Her mellifluous voice captivated the audience.

General.definition: To deliberately make something unclear or confusing.
General.example: The instructions seemed designed to obfuscate the process.

General.definition: Present or found everywhere.
General.example: Smartphones are ubiquitous in modern life.

General.definition: Exceedingly idealistic and impractical.
General.example: His plan to solve world hunger overnight was quixotic.

General.definition: Resistant to authority or control.
General.example: The recalcitrant student ignored all instructions.

General.definition: Intended for or likely understood by only a small number of people.
General.example: He has an esoteric knowledge of medieval literature.

General.definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed in words.
General.example: The view from the mountaintop was ineffable.

General.definition: Difficult to understand; obscure.
General.example: The book is full of abstruse philosophical concepts.

General.definition: Having keen mental discernment and good judgment.
General.example: Her sagacious advice helped him avoid mistakes.

General.definition: Belonging to a period other than that being portrayed.
General.example: The movie was full of anachronistic details.

General.definition: Noisy and difficult to control.
General.example: The obstreperous crowd delayed the show.

General.definition: Little known; abstruse.
General.example: He read recondite texts about ancient civilizations.

General.definition: Having a ready insight into things; perceptive.
General.example: Her perspicacious remarks impressed the committee.

General.definition: Showing a casual lack of concern; indifferent.
General.example: He strolled through life insouciant and carefree.

General.definition: Translucently clear.
General.example: The mountain lake was pellucid.

General.definition: Looking or sounding sad and dismal.
General.example: His lugubrious tone made everyone uncomfortable.

General.definition: Strongly reminiscent or suggestive of something.
General.example: The kitchen was redolent of fresh bread.

General.definition: Given to using long words; long-winded.
General.example: His sesquipedalian speech bored the audience.

General.definition: The act of throwing someone out of a window.
General.example: The historical defenestration caused a riot.

General.definition: Ridiculously old-fashioned; literally before the flood.
General.example: His antediluvian views angered the younger generation.

General.definition: Unwilling to change views or agree about something.
General.example: The negotiator was intransigent on key points.

General.definition: A change of circumstances or fortune, typically unwelcome.
General.example: He endured the vicissitudes of a military career.

General.definition: Deceitful and untrustworthy.
General.example: The perfidious ally betrayed them at the last moment.

General.definition: Showing a lack of courage or determination; timid.
General.example: The pusillanimous leader avoided confrontation.

General.definition: Unattractive and objectionable.
General.example: The rebarbative architecture put off tourists.

General.definition: Occurring before something else; predate.
General.example: The discovery antedated all previous theories.

General.definition: Strong public criticism or verbal abuse.
General.example: The politician faced obloquy after the scandal.

General.definition: Tending to induce sleep.
General.example: The lecture was soporific.

General.definition: The state of being close to someone or something; proximity.
General.example: The propinquity of their offices fostered collaboration.

General.definition: Acting in place of another.
General.example: She assumed a vicariant role during the manager's absence.

General.definition: Stubbornly disobedient; rebellious.
General.example: The contumacious student refused to leave the classroom.

General.definition: Added from an external source; not inherent.
General.example: The report contained adscititious data.

General.definition: Insisting on immediate attention or obedience; brusque.
General.example: The boss’s peremptory tone silenced the team.

General.definition: In a confused, rushed, or disorderly manner.
General.example: The students rushed pell-mell to the cafeteria.

General.definition: The quality of using long words.
General.example: His sesquipedality amused his linguist friends.

General.definition: Impossible to stop or prevent.
General.example: The inexorable march of time affects everyone.

General.definition: The state of being infatuated or obsessed with another person.
General.example: She felt limerence for her coworker.

General.definition: Shining brightly.
General.example: The refulgent sun illuminated the valley.

General.definition: Unable to be erased or forgotten.
General.example: The memory left an ineffaceable mark on him.

Technology.definition: The delay between an input and its corresponding output in a system.
Technology.example: High latency makes online gaming frustrating.

Technology.definition: The amount of data transferred in a given time.
Technology.example: The server's throughput increased after the upgrade.

Technology.definition: A practical approach to problem solving using shortcuts.
Technology.example: Heuristic algorithms speed up computations.

Technology.definition: Software that connects different applications or services.
Technology.example: The app relies on middleware to access the database.

Technology.definition: An operation that produces the same result no matter how many times it is applied.
Technology.example: HTTP PUT requests are idempotent.

Technology.definition: Restricting direct access to data by bundling it with methods.
Technology.example: Encapsulation protects object data in programming.

Technology.definition: The ability of systems to work together across platforms.
Technology.example: Interoperability is key in healthcare IT.

Technology.definition: A distributed ledger system for secure records.
Technology.example: Cryptocurrencies use blockchain technology.

Technology.definition: Packaging software with its dependencies into portable units.
Technology.example: Docker uses containerization to simplify deployment.

Technology.definition: When a quantum computer solves problems beyond classical computers.
Technology.example: Google claimed a milestone in quantum supremacy.

Technology.definition: Allows computation on encrypted data without decrypting it.
Technology.example: Homomorphic encryption ensures secure cloud computing.

Technology.definition: A cloud model where servers are managed by providers.
Technology.example: Serverless apps scale automatically with demand.

Technology.definition: Splitting a database into smaller, faster parts called shards.
Technology.example: Sharding improved the database performance.

Technology.definition: Creating virtual versions of computing resources.
Technology.example: Virtualization lets you run multiple OSes on one machine.

Technology.definition: Illegally using someone’s computer to mine cryptocurrency.
Technology.example: The malware was used for cryptojacking.

Technology.definition: Processing data closer to where it is generated.
Technology.example: Edge computing reduces latency for IoT devices.

Technology.definition: Proving possession of knowledge without revealing it.
Technology.example: Zero-knowledge proofs enable private blockchain transactions.

Technology.definition: Ability to measure a system’s internal state from outputs.
Technology.example: Observability is crucial for debugging systems.

Technology.definition: ML trained across devices without centralizing data.
Technology.example: Federated learning protects user privacy.

Technology.definition: Programming where operations are differentiable for optimization.
Technology.example: Differentiable programming powers modern AI frameworks.

Technology.definition: An architectural style that structures an app as small services.
Technology.example: Microservices allow independent deployment of features.

Technology.definition: Operations that do not occur at the same time.
Technology.example: Asynchronous calls improve web app responsiveness.

Technology.definition: Peculiar to an individual or system.
Technology.example: The software had an idiosyncratic error pattern.

Technology.definition: A function that calls itself.
Technology.example: Recursion is a common programming technique.

Technology.definition: Objects taking multiple forms in OOP.
Technology.example: Polymorphism simplifies code reuse.

Technology.definition: Hiding details to focus on high-level concepts.
Technology.example: Abstraction is key in software design.

Technology.definition: Executing multiple tasks simultaneously.
Technology.example: Concurrency improves server efficiency.

Technology.definition: Ability of a system to handle growth.
Technology.example: Scalability is essential for cloud apps.

Technology.definition: Reducing delays in data processing.
Technology.example: The engineers focused on latency optimization.

Technology.definition: Deliberately limiting data transfer rate.
Technology.example: Bandwidth throttling slowed the connection.

Technology.definition: Storing data temporarily for faster access.
Technology.example: Caching improved page load times.

Technology.definition: Distributing workloads across multiple resources.
Technology.example: Load balancing prevents server overload.

Technology.definition: System continues operating even when parts fail.
Technology.example: The database was designed with fault tolerance.

Technology.definition: A server that acts as a single entry point for APIs.
Technology.example: The API gateway manages client requests efficiently.

Business.definition: Buying and selling to profit from price differences.
Business.example: The trader engaged in currency arbitrage.

Business.definition: Combined effect greater than individual parts.
Business.example: The merger created synergy between the two companies.

Business.definition: Using resources to maximum advantage.
Business.example: They leveraged their network to grow quickly.

Business.definition: Comparing processes or performance to best practices.
Business.example: Benchmarking helped improve productivity.

Business.definition: Ability to grow or expand efficiently.
Business.example: The startup focused on scalability from day one.

Business.definition: Hiring external companies to handle business tasks.
Business.example: Outsourcing reduced operational costs.

Business.definition: Innovative and changing the market radically.
Business.example: The company introduced a disruptive technology.

Business.definition: A person with interest in a company/project.
Business.example: Stakeholders were invited to the meeting.

Business.definition: Investigating before a business decision.
Business.example: They performed due diligence before acquiring the firm.

Business.definition: Key performance indicators to measure success.
Business.example: They tracked KPIs to monitor progress.

Business.definition: Related to financial matters.
Business.example: The fiscal year ends in December.

Business.definition: A typical example of something.
Business.example: The CEO embodied the archetype of leadership.

Business.definition: Value derived from a brand name.
Business.example: Strong brand equity boosts sales.

Business.definition: Converting assets into revenue.
Business.example: App monetization is crucial for startups.

Business.definition: Changing strategy while keeping core elements.
Business.example: The company had to pivot after market failure.

Business.definition: Controlling multiple stages of production.
Business.example: Vertical integration reduced costs.

Business.definition: Ease of converting assets to cash.
Business.example: Liquidity is vital for business stability.

Business.definition: Distributing content or assets to multiple outlets.
Business.example: Syndication helped expand reach.

Business.definition: Protecting against financial risk.
Business.example: They used hedging to minimize losses.

Business.definition: A standard to measure performance.
Business.example: The benchmark was set high for quality.

Business.definition: Amount of capital raised for investment.
Business.example: Capitalization affects a company’s growth.

Business.definition: Difference between revenue and cost.
Business.example: High profit margin indicates efficiency.

Business.definition: Movement of money in and out of a business.
Business.example: Positive cash flow ensures operations.

Business.definition: Extent a product is recognized in the market.
Business.example: Market penetration increased after advertising.

Business.definition: An edge over rivals in the market.
Business.example: Quality service gives a competitive advantage.

Business.definition: Spreading investments to reduce risk.
Business.example: Diversification minimizes exposure to losses.

Business.definition: The promise of value to be delivered to customers.
Business.example: A clear value proposition attracts buyers.

Business.definition: Efficient management approach to reduce waste.
Business.example: Lean methodology improves productivity.

Business.definition: Analyzing strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, threats.
Business.example: They conducted a SWOT analysis for strategy.

Business.definition: Creating uncontested market space.
Business.example: The startup adopted a blue ocean strategy.

Business.definition: Obtaining services or ideas from a large group.
Business.example: They used crowdsourcing for design ideas.

Business.definition: Plan to leave a business or investment.
Business.example: The investors discussed an exit strategy.

Business.definition: How a brand is perceived in the market.
Business.example: Brand positioning distinguishes products from competitors.

Business.definition: Cost advantages due to increased production.
Business.example: Economies of scale lowered manufacturing costs.

Science.definition: Process by which plants convert sunlight into energy.
Science.example: Photosynthesis produces oxygen for the atmosphere.

Science.definition: Organelles that generate energy in cells.
Science.example: Mitochondria are often called the powerhouses of the cell.

Science.definition: Study of heat and energy transfer.
Science.example: Thermodynamics explains how engines work.

Science.definition: Variants of an element with different numbers of neutrons.
Science.example: Carbon-14 is a radioactive isotope.

Science.definition: Movement of water through a membrane.
Science.example: Plants absorb water through osmosis.

Science.definition: A massive star explosion.
Science.example: A supernova can outshine an entire galaxy.

Science.definition: A fundamental particle that makes up protons and neutrons.
Science.example: Quarks are essential to nuclear physics.

Science.definition: Measure of disorder in a system.
Science.example: Entropy always increases in isolated systems.

Science.definition: A substance that speeds up a chemical reaction.
Science.example: Enzymes act as catalysts in the body.

Science.definition: A substance made of large molecules of repeating units.
Science.example: Plastic is a common synthetic polymer.

Science.definition: Manipulation of matter at the atomic level.
Science.example: Nanotechnology is used in medicine and electronics.

Science.definition: Study of changes in gene expression not caused by DNA sequence changes.
Science.example: Epigenetics shows how environment affects health.

Science.definition: Theory explaining movement of Earth’s crustal plates.
Science.example: Plate tectonics cause earthquakes and volcanoes.

Science.definition: A mysterious form of matter that does not emit light.
Science.example: Dark matter makes up most of the universe’s mass.

Science.definition: Variety of life in a particular habitat.
Science.example: Rainforests have high biodiversity.

Science.definition: Step-by-step procedure for calculations.
Science.example: Algorithms power search engines.

Science.definition: Junction between two nerve cells.
Science.example: Signals travel across a synapse using neurotransmitters.

Science.definition: Science of classification of organisms.
Science.example: Taxonomy places humans in the primate order.

Science.definition: Study of materials at extremely low temperatures.
Science.example: Cryogenics is used to preserve biological samples.

Science.definition: A quantum state where particles remain linked.
Science.example: Quantum entanglement puzzled Einstein himself.

Arts.definition: Concerned with beauty or artistic taste.
Arts.example: The painting has a minimalist aesthetic.

Arts.definition: Arrangement of elements in art or music.
Arts.example: The composition of the photo draws the eye to the center.

Arts.definition: Range of colors used in art.
Arts.example: The artist used a pastel palette.

Arts.definition: Technique to represent three dimensions on a flat surface.
Arts.example: The drawing uses one-point perspective.

Arts.definition: A story with a hidden moral or political meaning.
Arts.example: The novel is an allegory of freedom.

Arts.definition: A recurring element in art or literature.
Arts.example: The motif of light appears throughout the play.

Arts.definition: 20th-century art movement focused on dreams and imagination.
Arts.example: Dali’s paintings are classic surrealism.

Arts.definition: Rhythmic flow of sounds or words.
Arts.example: The poem ends with a calming cadence.

Arts.definition: Art in a single color.
Arts.example: The photograph was shot in monochrome.

Arts.definition: Art style capturing light and movement with quick brushstrokes.
Arts.example: Monet is famous for impressionism.

Arts.definition: Use of light and shadow in art.
Arts.example: Caravaggio mastered chiaroscuro.

Arts.definition: Decorative handwriting or lettering.
Arts.example: The invitation was written in calligraphy.

Arts.definition: The rise and fall of voice in speech or singing.
Arts.example: Her intonation gave the song emotion.

Arts.definition: Representation of real-world objects in art.
Arts.example: Figuration contrasts with abstraction.

Arts.definition: Music with multiple independent melodies.
Arts.example: Polyphony is common in Renaissance music.

Arts.definition: Mural painting on wet plaster.
Arts.example: Michelangelo’s Sistine Chapel is a fresco.

Arts.definition: A recurring musical theme associated with a character or idea.
Arts.example: The villain’s leitmotif played during his entrance.

Arts.definition: Art style focused on simplicity and limited elements.
Arts.example: Minimalism emphasizes clean lines.

Arts.definition: The part of a stage in front of the curtain.
Arts.example: The play was performed on a proscenium stage.

Arts.definition: Ornamental design featuring intertwined lines; also a ballet position.
Arts.example: The dancer held a perfect arabesque.
